sectionBreak.stem:
The following function defines a curve with several unequal minima over the interval: 2 ≤ x ≤ 20

 

%media:formula1.mml%

internal_category.title: ABET Outcomes: (a) an ability to apply knowledge of mathematics, science, and engineering

doc.stem:
Develop a MATLAB script to plot the function over the interval. Upload the script and the plot obtained.

 

(Please upload your response/solution using the controls below.)

internal_category.title: ABET Outcomes: (a) an ability to apply knowledge of mathematics, science, and engineering

property.name: problemSolution
property.value:
The point of minimum is x = 5.3622.

The value of minimum is f (x) = –1.2160.

hint.name: hint #1
hint.value: What are the arguments required to find the minimum of a function using MATLAB?

worksheet.stem:
Determine the minimum and the value of the minimum of the function with fminbnd. Use initial guesses of [4, 8]. (Round the final answers to four decimal places.)

 

The point of the minimum is x = __A__.

 

The value of the function at the minimum is f (x) = __B__.
worksheet.commonFeedback:
The MATLAB script to find the minimum of the function is 

 

clear,clc,clf
format compact
x=[2:0.125:20];
[xmin,fmin]=fminbnd(@fff,4,8)

 

The MATLAB function fff holds the given function:


function fx = fff(x)
fx = sin(x) + sin(2*x/3);
end
 

Output

 

xmin =

    5.3622

fmin =

   -1.2160

internal_category.title: ABET Outcomes: (a) an ability to apply knowledge of mathematics, science, and engineering

property.name: problemSolution
property.value:
The point of minimum is x = 5.3623.

The value of minimum is f (x) = –1.2160.

hint.name: hint #1
hint.value: How are the interior points created using golden section search?

worksheet.stem:
Determine the minimum of the function by hand with the golden-section search with a stopping criterion corresponding to three significant figures. Use initial guesses of [4, 8]. (Round the final answer to four decimal places.)

 

The point of the minimum is x = __A__.

 

The value of the function at the minimum is f (x) = __B__.

property.name: problemSolution
property.value: The maximum f (xmax) = 2.1125 occurs at the location xmax = 1.1725. The approximate relative error is 0.0707%.

hint.name: hint #1
hint.value: Can the golden-section search be used to find the maximum of any function?

worksheet.stem:
Use the golden-section search to determine the location, xmax, and maximum, f (xmax), of the following function by hand:

 

%media:formula3.mml%

 

Use initial guesses of xl = 0.7 and xu = 1.4 and perform sufficient iterations so that εs = 10%. Determine the approximate relative error of your final result. (Round the final answers to four decimal places.)

 

The maximum f (xmax) = __A__ occurs at the location xmax = __B__. The approximate relative error is __C__ %.
worksheet.commonFeedback:
The golden-section search is used to determine the minimum of a one-dimensional function. The maximum of f (x) will be the minimum the function –f (x).

 

The steps to find the minimum of the function g (x) = –f (x) can be tabulated as follows:

 

i xl g (xl) x2 g (x2) x1 g (x1) xu g (xu) d xopt g (xopt) εa
1 0.7000 –1.4859 0.9674 –1.958 1.1326 –2.106 1.4000 –1.839 0.4326 1.1326 –2.1057 23.6068%
2 0.9674 –1.9582 1.1326 –2.106 1.2348 –2.095 1.4000 –1.839 0.2674 1.1326 –2.1057 14.5898%
3 0.9674 –1.9582 1.0695 –2.07 1.1326 –2.106 1.2348 –2.095 0.1652 1.1326 –2.1057 9.0170%
4 1.0695 –2.0698 1.1326 –2.106 1.1716 –2.112 1.2348 –2.095 0.1021 1.1716 –2.1125 5.3873%
5 1.1326 –2.1057 1.1716 –2.112 1.1957 –2.11 1.2348 –2.095 0.0631 1.1716 –2.1125 3.3295%
6 1.1326 –2.1057 1.1567 –2.111 1.1716 –2.112 1.1957 –2.11 0.0390 1.1716 –2.1125 2.0578%
7 1.1567 –2.1114 1.1716 –2.112 1.1808 –2.112 1.1957 –2.11 0.0241 1.1716 –2.1125 1.2718%
8 1.1567 –2.1114 1.1659 –2.112 1.1716 –2.112 1.1808 –2.112 0.0149 1.1716 –2.1125 0.7860%
9 1.1659 –2.1123 1.1716 –2.112 1.1752 –2.112 1.1808 –2.112 0.0092 1.1716 –2.1125 0.4858%
10 1.1659 –2.1123 1.1695 –2.112 1.1716 –2.112 1.1752 –2.112 0.0057 1.1716 –2.1125 0.3002%
11 1.1695 –2.1125 1.1716 –2.112 1.1730 –2.112 1.1752 –2.112 0.0035 1.1730 –2.1125 0.1853%
12 1.1716 –2.1125 1.1730 –2.112 1.1738 –2.112 1.1752 –2.112 0.0022 1.1730 –2.1125 0.1145%
13 1.1716 –2.1125 1.1725 –2.112 1.1730 –2.112 1.1738 –2.112 0.0013 1.1725 –2.1125 0.0707%

 

Thus, the maximum of f (x) occurs at 1.1725.

 

The maximum value of f (x) is

 

%media:formula4.mml%

internal_category.title: ABET Outcomes: (a) an ability to apply knowledge of mathematics, science, and engineering

hint.name: hint #1
hint.value: How can the maximum of a function be found using golden-section search?

worksheet.stem:
The trajectory of a ball can be computed with

 

%media:formula2.mml%

 

where y = the height (m), θ0 = the initial angle (radians), v0 = the initial velocity (m/s), g = the gravitational constant = 9.81 m/s2, and y0 = the initial height (m). Use the golden-section search to determine the maximum height given y0 = 2 m, v0 = 20 m/s, and θ0 = 45°. Iterate until the approximate error falls below εs = 10% using initial guesses of xl = 10 m and xu = 30 m. (Round the final answer to three decimal places.)

 

The maximum height is __A__ m.
worksheet.commonFeedback:
The first iteration of the golden-section search can be implemented as

 

%media:formula5.mml%

 

%media:formula6.mml%

 

%media:formula7.mml%

 

%media:formula8.mml%

 

%media:formula9.mml%

 

Because f(x1) > f(x2), the maximum is in the interval defined by x2, x1, and xu where x1 is the optimum. The error at this point can be computed as

 

%media:formula10.mml%

 

i xl f (xl) x2 f (x2) x1 f (x1) xu f (xu) d xopt f (xopt) εa

3 17.639 12.008 20.557 12.193 22.361 12.098 25.279 11.607 4.721 20.557 12.193 14.19%
4 17.639 12.008 19.443 12.172 20.557 12.193 22.361 22.361 2.918 20.557 12.193 8.77%

sectionBreak.stem:
The given figure shows a pinned-fixed beam subject to a uniform load. The equation for the resulting deflections is

 

%media:formula11.mml%

 

Use the following parameter values in your computation (make sure that you use consistent units): L = 400 cm, E = 52,000 kN/cm2, I = 32,000 cm4, and w = 4 kN/cm.

 

%media:p-7-41.jpg%

internal_category.title: ABET Outcomes: (a) an ability to apply knowledge of mathematics, science, and engineering

doc.stem:
Develop a MATLAB script that uses fminbnd to generate a labeled plot of deflection versus distance and determine the location and magnitude of the maximum deflection. Employ initial guesses of 0 and L and use optimset to display the iterations. Upload the MATLAB script and the plot obtained.

 

(Please upload your response/solution using the controls below.)
doc.info: question data is all stored in questionProperties...

internal_category.title: ABET Outcomes: (a) an ability to apply knowledge of mathematics, science, and engineering

property.name: problemSolution
property.value: The maximum y = 3.3330 × 10–3 m occurs at the location x = 1.6861 m.

hint.name: hint #1
hint.value: What are the arguments required for MATLAB’s fminbnd function?

worksheet.stem:
Use MATLAB to determine the location and magnitude of the maximum deflection. Employ initial guesses of 0 and L. (Round the final answers to four decimal places.)

 

The maximum y = __A__ × 10–3 m occurs at the location x = __B__ m.
worksheet.commonFeedback:
The following script can be developed to determine the location and magnitude of the maximum deflection with MATLAB’s fminbnd function,

 

clear;clc;
w=4*1e3*100;L=400/100;E=52000*1e3*1e4;I=32000/100^4;
f = @(x) -w/(48*E*I)*(2*x.^4-3*L*x.^3+L^3*x);

options=optimset('display','iter');
format long
[xopt,opt]=fminbnd(f,0,L,options);
xopt
maxdeflection=-opt

 

When this is run, the result is

 

Func-count     x          f(x)         Procedure
    1        1.52786  -0.00329941        initial
    2        2.47214  -0.00258495        golden
    3       0.944272  -0.00260016        golden
    4        1.70431  -0.00333256        parabolic
    5        1.68674    -0.003333        parabolic
    6        1.68621    -0.003333        parabolic
    7        1.68614    -0.003333        parabolic
    8        1.68617    -0.003333        parabolic
    9        1.68611    -0.003333        parabolic
 
Optimization terminated:
 the current x satisfies the termination criteria using OPTIONS.TolX of 1.000000e-04


xopt =

   1.686140310219162


maxdeflection =

   0.003332997911279

internal_category.title: ABET Outcomes: (a) an ability to apply knowledge of mathematics, science, and engineering

property.name: problemSolution
property.value: The optimal steady cruise velocity is 248.5868 m/s.

hint.name: hint #1
hint.value: What are the arguments required for MATLAB's fminbnd function?

worksheet.stem:
%media:p-7-42.jpg%

 

For a jet in steady, level flight, thrust balances drag and lift balances weight (see the figure). Under these conditions, the optimal cruise speed occurs when the ratio of drag force to velocity is minimized. The drag, CD, can be computed as

 

%media:formula12.mml%

 

where CD0 = drag coefficient at zero lift, CL = the lift coefficient, and AR = the aspect ratio. For steady, level flight, the lift coefficient can be computed as

 

%media:formula13.mml%

 

where W = the jet’s weight (N), ρ = air density (kg/m3), v = velocity (m/s), and A = wing planform area (m2). The drag force can then be computed as

 

%media:formula14.mml%

 

Use these formulas to determine the optimal steady cruise velocity for a 670 kN jet flying at 10 km above sea level. Employ the following parameters in your computation: A = 150 m2, AR = 6.5, CD0 = 0.018, and ρ = 0.413 kg/m3. (Round the final answer to four decimal places.)

 

The optimal steady cruise velocity is __A__ m/s.
worksheet.commonFeedback:
The following MATLAB script can be employed to generate the solution using the fminbnd function:

 

clear,clc
W=670000;CD0=0.018;rho=0.413;A=150;AR=6.5;
[v,FDv]=fminbnd(@FDoverv,100,500,[],W,CD0,rho,A,AR)

function [FDv] = FDoverv(v,W,CD0,rho,A,AR)
CL=2*W/rho/v^2/A;
CD=CD0+CL^2/pi/AR;
FD=W*CD/CL;
FDv=FD/v;
end

 

Results:

 

v =

  248.5868


FDv =

  184.7995

internal_category.title: ABET Outcomes: (a) an ability to apply knowledge of mathematics, science, and engineering

sectionBreak.stem:
%media:p-7-42.jpg%

 

For a jet in steady, level flight, thrust balances drag and lift balances weight (see the figure). Under these conditions, the optimal cruise speed occurs when the ratio of drag force to velocity is minimized. The drag, CD, can be computed as

 

%media:formula15.mml%

 

where CD0 = drag coefficient at zero lift, CL = the lift coefficient, and AR = the aspect ratio. For steady, level flight, the lift coefficient can be computed as

 

%media:formula16.mml%

 

where W = the jet’s weight (N), ρ = air density (kg/m3), v = velocity (m/s), and A = wing planform area (m2). The drag force can then be computed as

 

%media:formula17.mml%

 

Employ a mass of 68,300 kg for the jet. The other parameters are A = 150 m2, AR = 6.5, CD0 = 0.018, and ρ = 0.413 kg/m3. Note that the gravitational acceleration at 45° latitude can be computed as a function of elevation with

 

%media:formula18.mml%

 

where g(h) = gravitational acceleration (m∕s2) at elevation h (m) above sea level, and re = Earth’s mean radius (= 6.371 × 106 m). In addition, air density as a function of elevation can be calculated with

 

%media:formula19.mml%

internal_category.title: ABET Outcomes: (a) an ability to apply knowledge of mathematics, science, and engineering

doc.stem:
Develop a MATLAB script to generate a plot of the optimal velocity of the jet versus elevation above sea level. Design the plot for elevations ranging from h = 0 to 12 km above sea level.

 

(Please upload your response/solution using the controls below.)

property.name: problemSolution
property.value: The solutions are as follows: θ = 50.0410°, x1 = 0.1193 m, x2 = 0.9381 m, xwetted = 0.8189 m.

hint.name: hint #1
hint.value: The coverage is maximized for the trajectory that just clears the top front corner. That is, choose x1 and θ that just clear the top corner while maximizing x2 – x1.

worksheet.stem:
%media:p-7-44.jpg%

 

As depicted in the figure, a mobile fire hose projects a stream of water onto the roof of a building. At what angle, θ, and how far from the building, x1, should the hose be placed in order to maximize the coverage of the roof, that is, to maximize: x2 – x1? Note that the water velocity leaving the nozzle has a constant value of 3 m/s regardless of the angle, and the other parameter values are h1 = 0.06 m, h2 = 0.2 m, and L = 0.12 m. (Round the final answers to four decimal places.)

 

The solutions are as follows:

 

   θ = __A__ (in degrees)

 

   x1 = __B__ m

 

   x2 = __C__ m

 

   xwetted = __D__ m
worksheet.commonFeedback:
If t = 0 is defined as the time at which each water droplet leaves the nozzle, the x and y coordinates can be computed as a function of time with

 

%media:formula20.mml%

 

%media:formula21.mml%

 

By setting y = h2, the second equation becomes

 

%media:formula22.mml%

 

which can be solved with the quadratic formula as

 

%media:formula23.mml%

 

%media:formula24.mml%

 

where t1 = the time at which the stream just clears the front of the roof (s), and t2 = the time at which the stream lands on the surface (s). For the x equation, set t = t1 and solve for

 

%media:formula25.mml%

 

The distance to the point where the stream hits the roof can then be determined by substituting t = t2.

 

%media:formula26.mml%

 

Therefore, the length of roof that can be watered is%media:formula27.mml%.

 

MATLAB can then be used to determine the value of θ that maximizes this function. Here is one way to do that:

 

clear;clc
format compact
h1=0.06;h2=0.2;L=0.12;
v0=3;g=9.81;
angle=fminbnd(@f,35,70,[],v0,g,h1,h2,L)
[x1,x2]=fth(angle,v0,g,h1,h2,L)
xwetted=x2-x1

function [dx] = f(thetad,v0,g,h1,h2,L)
[x1,x2]=fth(thetad,v0,g,h1,h2,L);
dx=x1-x2;
end

function [x1,x2] = fth(thetad,v0,g,h1,h2,L)
theta=thetad*pi/180;
disc=v0^2*sin(theta)^2-2*g*(h2-h1-L*sin(theta));
t1=(v0*sin(theta)-sqrt(disc))/g;
t2=(v0*sin(theta)+sqrt(disc))/g;
x1=L*cos(theta)+v0*cos(theta)*t1;
x2=L*cos(theta)+v0*cos(theta)*t2;
end

 

When the script is run, the result is

 

angle =
   50.041
x1 =
    0.1193
x2 =
   0.93813
xwetted =
   0.81885

internal_category.title: ABET Outcomes: (a) an ability to apply knowledge of mathematics, science, and engineering

doc.stem:
%media:p-7-45.jpg%

 

Since many pollutants enter lakes (and other water bodies for that matter) at their peripheries, an important water quality problem involves modeling the distribution of contaminants in the vicinity of a waste discharge or a river. For a vertically well-mixed, constant-depth layer, the steady-state distribution of a pollutant reacting with first-order decay is represented by

 

%media:formula28.mml%

 

where the x and y axes are defined to be parallel and perpendicular to the shoreline, respectively (see the figure). The parameters and variables are as follows:Ux = the water velocity along the shoreline (m/d), c = concentration, E = the turbulent diffusion coefficient, and k = the first-order decay rate. For the case where a constant loading, W, enters at (0, 0), the solution for the concentration at any coordinate is given by

 

%media:formula29.mml%

 

where

 

%media:formula30.mml%

 

where Y = the width, H = depth, and K0 = the modified Bessel function of the second kind.

 

Develop a MATLAB script to generate a contour plot of concentration for a section of a lake with Y = 4.8 km and a length from X = –2.4 to 2.4 km using Δx = Δy = 0.32 km. Employ the following parameters for your calculation: W = 1.2 × 1012, H = 20, E = 5 × 106, Ux = 5 × 103, k = 1, and n = 3.

 

(Please upload your response/solution using the controls below.)
